Award.AwardTitle: Improving Communication of Oil Spill Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Metcalf Institute for Marine & Environmental Reporting at the University of Rhode Island Graduate School of Oceanography is implementing a three-stage sequence of workshops that will bring together science journalists, communications professionals, informal science education professionals, and NSF-funded (RAPID) research scientists who are studying the Deepwater Horizon oil rig failure and its impact on the Gulf of Mexico. During this period of focused interest by the public, the three stages will allow for an iterative process of capacity-building by journalists and informal science educators that will result in a set of experiences and resources to improve the public understanding of the oil spill's impacts and the specific scientific techniques used to assess the impacts. The project's outcomes also include strengthening the communication skills of the research scientists via new media and talks tailored to journalists and informal science educators.

The three stages are: (1) Three sessions at the October 2010 conference of the Society of Environmental Journalists; (2) an April 2011 2.5-day seminar in Louisiana co-hosted by Louisiana State University and Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium (including field experience on an LSU research vessel); and (3) a June 2011 week-long "science immersion workshop" (including laboratory and field experience on a URI research vessel) and five associated public lectures at the Metcalf Institute, including web cast live via Internet2.

The three programs are being evaluated by faculty at the Public Policy Research Lab of LSU Manship School of Mass Communication.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Improving Communication of Oil Spill Research, or ICOSR project, had five goals, to be attained via a three-part project:

  1. Inform journalists and informal science educators (ISEs) about emerging research on the Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill (DHOS);
  2. Encourage dissemination of RAPID-funded research to the public;
  3. Provide journalists and ISEs with a better understanding of scientific methods, the research process, and peer review;
  4. Assess the value of combined training for journalists and ISEs; and finally
  5. Assess the impacts of the science training on the quality of reporting on the DHOS.

 

The ICOSR project had three stages. The first stage brought three NSF RAPID-funded researchers to the 2010 conference of the Society of Environmental Journalists (SEJ). Researchers gave three talks over the course of the 5-day conference about the major scientific questions that had arisen as a result of the DHOS. Each was interviewed and the edited interviews were posted on the Metcalf Institute Web site and YouTube channel. As of October 2011, these videos had garnered over 700 views. The ICOSR project also brought two graduate students to the SEJ conference to contribute scientific perspectives on the conference sessions and to improve their science communication skills.

 

The second stage involved a 3-day science seminar on the emerging research about the DHOS, held April 2011 at the Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium (LUMCON) laboratory facilities in Cocodrie, LA. This science seminar was novel in that it included both journalists and ISEs. The journalists and educators were equal in number and the two professions were mixed together throughout the program. This was purposeful, as the program intended to assess the value of pooling science communication professionals together to learn from one another regarding the communication of risk in general and DHOS science in particular.

 

The third stage of the ICOSR project was a one-week science immersion program for journalists. This one-week program was the 13th annual Metcalf Institute Science Immersion Workshop for Journalists, held June 2011. The annual workshop focuses on a different theme each year, and the ICOSR project allowed the workshop to focus exclusively on the science of the Deepwater Horizon spill.

 

Each of the five stated goals was accomplished within the ICOSR project. Goals one and two were achieved within each part of the project, while the April and June science immersion programs also achieved goal three. The assessment of combined training for journalists and ISEs and media analysis was applied only to the April Science Seminar.

 

Society of Environmental Journalists conference

The inclusion of three RAPID-funded oil spill researchers and two graduate students in the annual SEJ conference was a great success. Metcalf Institute organized three sessions with the oil spill researchers. The sessions were attending by a total of approximately 50-75 journalists, and each session inspired a great deal of discussion between the researchers and attending journalists. One of the participating scientists and one of the graduate students collaborated as a result of their conference attendance and currently have a co-authored paper in press about the DHOS.
